Package simple.gui

Class Widget

  • java.lang.Object
    • simple.gui.Widget
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Button, EmptyWidget, HexWidget, ImageBox, Panel, PanelCollection, ScrollBox, Slider, TextArea

    public abstract class Widget
extends java.lang.Object
    Generic Widget class. All widgets inherit from this class.

    The idea behind widgets is to create interfaceable components to perform tasks. These could be buttons, scrollboxes, textboxes, or possibly panels to contain other widgets. Many generic widgets are defined here, but the goal behind this class was to create a system to easily allow you to make your own components.

    Note that if you decide to make your own Widget object, they have access to a DrawObject named draw. Drawing should be done with this object.

    Widget is an abstract class, as it's meant to be the framework for other widgets.

    Author:
    Austin Mitchell

      • _blocked

        protected boolean _blocked
        Another state of allowed interaction specifically with the mouse. Note the difference between isBlocked and enabled, apparent when you draw a disabled button vs. a blocked button.

      • intersectsWith

        public static boolean intersectsWith​(Widget w1,
                                     Widget w2)
        Method to determine whether two widgets intersect within a bounding box by default. Behaviour may be changed within individual widget classes with the non-static method. Note that as it stands, given two widgets a and b, Widget.intersectsWith(a, b) and Widget.intersectsWith(b, a) may give different results, as w1 does not take into account w2's behaviour for intersectsWith(w1).
        Parameters:
        w1 - Widget object whose intersectsWith(Widget w) will be called.
        w2 - Widget object whose only relevant pieces of information in this method are its x, y, w, and h values.

        public boolean intersectsWith​(int x,

      • containsMouse

        public boolean containsMouse​()
        Returns whether the mouse's x and y coordinates are contained within the widgets bounds. Overwriting encourages if alternate behaviour is needed.

      • hovering

        public boolean hovering​()
        Returns the widget's hovering variable.

        Hovering is defined as the mouse being contained by the widget, but with the mouse unpressed.

      • clicking

        public boolean clicking​()
        Returns the widget's clicking variable.

        Clicking is defined as the mouse being contained by the widget, with the mouse currently pressing down the button.

      • clicked

        public boolean clicked​()
        Returns the widget's clicked variable.

        Clicked is defined as the mouse being contained by the widget, with the mouse unpressed, but was clicking in the direct previous frame.

      • updateClickingState

        protected void updateClickingState​()
        Updates the widget's state relative to the mouse. This must be physically called in your widget's local Update() function for any mouse activity to register.

      • update

        public final void update​()

      • draw

        public final void draw​()

      • updateWidget

        protected abstract void updateWidget​()
        Method which must be implemented by your widget. The status of the widget and it's info should be modified and regulated here every frame.

      • drawWidget

        protected abstract void drawWidget​()
        Method which must be implemented by your widget. Any draw functions for your widget should be called here, and drawn every frame relative to the widget's status.

      • drawCustom

        public void drawCustom​(CustomDraw cd)

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString​()
        Basic toString() function that returns the widget's class name, x and y coordinate, and width and height
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
